author: Rogue_Colonel
title: Ideal vehicle to patrol the high seas with..
review:
I never got the first version of this set (7739) but it was one I always wanted so when this new version came out I wanted to lay my hands on it.

Firstly it's an easy build, all comes in the usual modular bag system: -

Bag1: Speedboat/Helecopter
Bag2: Speedboat
Bag3: Base half of the main Coastguard ship
Bag4: Upper half of the ship

For so many pieces I completed this in just over an hour.

Pros

  • Boats are impressive and really float
  • Both would make excellent bases for MOC's
  • Fit in really well with both Marina sets issued and previous Coastguard sets
  • Lots of play elements (but why would a Coastguard ship have an ROV?)

Cons

  • Stickers, lots of stickers.  Probably to be expected for a set of this nature though
  • Boring minifigs, the figures are fine if functional but nothing exceptional

This is a great set and fits in really well with other Lego ships.  I think this is a better set than the previous one but I really liked the tower that came with that set.  The Coastguard sets are a bit hit or miss this time round but I think this is a definite hit.

author: HuskyDynamics
title: 60014 Coast Guard Patrol
review:
Overall:

This is a really nice set.  I acquired it several years ago, when it was released, and now realized that I should write a review on it.  This is a very nice set.  There is a very clear story element behind this set, with a clear intent of rescuing the poor people who crashed their boat into a lighthouse (how that would happen is beyond me, but still).  The lighthouse is built quite simply while still being obviously recognizable as one.  The small green boat is nice, although it is a bit lacking in detail.

The star of the set is the Coast Guard cutter.  This is a very nice-looking ship which also has a detailed bridge.  Since there is so much to say, I will simply give a list of pros and cons below.

 

Pros:

This ship looks great with the stickers included in the set.

The helicopter, while very small, is still quite swooshable (I love saying that word).

The bridge superstructure looks amazing with those angled windows.  There is a good minifigure selection, as well as a dog, 3 sharks, and a crab.

I love the little radar array on the top of the Coast Guard vessel.

The set comes with 2 "floaty boat" hulls.

 

Cons:

The helicopter has a very limited landing space, and when onboard the ship, obscures the view forward from the bridge (so the Coast Guard may well run into that same lighthouse because they can't see).

Other than the bridge, there is no interior to the ship, only a low crawlspace under the bridge.

There is no lifeboat/small rescue boat included in the set.

The mini ROV (remotely operated vehicle, the minisub thing) seems kind of irrelevant to the set.

 

Modifications:

Recently, to rectify these problems, I have modified this set using miscellaneous pieces.  NOTE: If all you are looking for is info about the set, feel free to stop reading here.  Or read on, if you like.

Anyways, I have added parts from several sets, as well as some generic elements that I had lying around.  I moved the helipad to the back and elevated it above the deck using an 8x8 octagon-shaped plate, as well as adding a relatively detailed lower deck under the superstructure.  I built an engine room towards the back, as well as a small bunkroom (small as in one bed) forward.  This also allows access from the front of the vessel to the back, a big plus.  For a smaller modification, I moved the minisub davit (or crane, whatever) to the front and mounted the small boat from 60012 Coast Guard 4x4 and Diving Boat on the conveniently located clip.

 

Well, that's about all that I have to say, so thanks for taking the time to read my review of 60014 Coast Guard Patrol!
